docs.snippet: The New Old Age     From Jane Gross's blog, nytimes.com/newoldage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Top city officials held a press conference on Monday to reassure New Yorkers that despite a weekend that reshaped the landscape of Wall Street, the city had long been fiscally prudent in preparing for a downturn in the financial sector."The things that New Yorkers need to know is that we planned for a day like today," said Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, trying to quell fears on a day where the storied Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Merrill Lynch announced it would be bought by Bank of America New York State allowed the insurance giant A.I.G. to access $20 billion in subsidiary assets, and the Dow had the largest drop since the days after 9/11.

headline.main: Financial Assurances: 'We Planned for a Day Like Today'

docs.abstract: Top city officials hold a press conference to emphasize that the city is fiscally prepared to weather a Wall Street downturn.

docs.lead_paragraph: In this first installment of Trade and the Economy Watch, Joanna R. Shelton tells us why, when it comes to the economy, her red state of Montana just might go blue in this presidential election.

headline.main: It's the Economy; at Least in Montana It Is

docs.abstract: Why my red state may go blue in November.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated: The Federal Reserve has asked JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to help gather $70 billion to $75 billion in loans to help prop up the American International Group, the giant insurance company, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline.main: Fed Seeks At Least $70 Billion to Help A.I.G.

docs.abstract: Updated: The Federal Reserve has asked JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to help gather $70 billion to $75 billion in loans to help prop up the American International Group, the giant insurance company, according to a person briefed on the matter. More specific details of the plan could not be learned, but it appears that [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Your Money writers Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard answered readers’ questions about the impact of the turmoil in the financial services industry on consumers and investors.
docs.snippet: Your Money writers Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard answered readers’ questions about the impact of the turmoil in the financial services industry on consumers and investors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two prominent Wall Street firms have faltered, with Merrill Lynch agreeing to sell itself to Bank of America for roughly $50 billion to avert a deepening financial crisis. And another prominent securities company, Lehman Brothers, filed for bankruptcy protection and hurtled toward liquidation after it failed to find a buyer after a Sunday filled with brinkmanship.
docs.abstract: Also in Morning Buzz: A City Council bill would make voters arbiters of term limits. And other headlines from newspapers around the region.

docs.lead_paragraph: A crisis of confidence in financial markets on Wall Street culminated in a weekend of brinksmanship and failed appeals that caused the demise of some of the nation's storied financial institutions, The New York Times's financial team reported in its comprehensive coverage of the weekend.
